reasoning:
The critique targets the essay’s conditional pessimism in §3.2 that if the correct (or dominant) views are non-discounting and roughly linear-in-resources, gains from moral trade/compromise may be small because there’s little “satiation” and limited resource-compatibility. If that pessimism were overturned, the essay would be somewhat more optimistic about reaching mostly-great futures via trade, but it would not collapse the broader position (which also emphasizes threats, power concentration, lock-in, weak convergence, etc.), so centrality is moderate-low.

On strength: the essay already explicitly notes location-of-resources, time-to-access, and other friction-like reasons for trade (including speed-of-light/uncertainty) in §3.1, so the core move (“physics makes distant resources less valuable/more costly to realize”) is substantially ‘priced in.’ Moreover, higher acquisition costs or access constraints don’t by themselves create the kind of diminishing marginal utility/“easy satiation” that makes compromise broadly value-preserving for linear views; they more directly create heterogeneous marginal values over *which* resources are usable/soon-usable, which the essay already treats as a basis for trade but not as solving incompatibility between highly particular linear objectives. So it weakens the targeted worry only a bit.

Correctness is middling: it’s true that physics (latency, coordination limits, thermodynamics) constrains effective control and can create strong locality effects, but claims like “exponential costs beyond a radius” are not established and aren’t generally true without extra assumptions. Clarity is high and it stays on one issue with little dead weight.
title: Physical constraints impose effective diminishing returns even on linear maximizers
